title: Job Chapter 21 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Job chapter 21 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Job Chapter 21 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Job Chapter 21.

questions.question: Who is speaking in Job 21?
questions.correctAnswer: Job
questions.explanation: Job is the speaker in this chapter, as indicated in Job 21:1, 'But Job answered and said'.

questions.question: What does Job ask to be allowed to do before others mock him?
questions.correctAnswer: To speak
questions.explanation: Job requests to be allowed to speak before others mock him, as stated in Job 21:3.

questions.question: According to Job 21:7, who does Job question about living long and being powerful?
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked
questions.explanation: Job questions why the wicked live long and are mighty in power in Job 21:7.

questions.question: What do the wicked have established before their eyes according to Job 21:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Their seed and offspring
questions.explanation: Job says their seed and offspring are established in their sight, as found in Job 21:8.

questions.question: What musical instruments are mentioned in Job 21:12?
questions.correctAnswer: Timbrel and harp
questions.explanation: Job 21:12 mentions the timbrel and harp as instruments the wicked use to rejoice.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Therefore they say unto God, ______ from us; for we desire not the knowledge of thy ways.'
questions.correctAnswer: Depart
questions.explanation: The verse Job 21:14 states they say to God, 'Depart from us; for we desire not the knowledge of thy ways.'

questions.question: True or False: Job 21:15 asks what profit is there if we pray unto the Almighty.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 21:15 asks, 'What profit should we have, if we pray unto him?' confirming the question about profit.

questions.question: According to Job 21:17, how does God distribute sorrows?
questions.correctAnswer: In his anger
questions.explanation: Job 21:17 says God distributeth sorrows in his anger.

questions.question: What happens to the wicked according to Job 21:18?
options: They are as stubble before the wind
questions.correctAnswer: They are as stubble before the wind
questions.explanation: Job 21:18 compares the wicked to stubble before the wind and chaff carried by the storm.

questions.question: Who judges those that are high, as mentioned in Job 21:22?
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Job 21:22 states that God judges those that are high.

questions.question: True or False: Job describes someone dying in his full strength and being at ease in Job 21:23.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 21:23 describes one who dies in full strength, wholly at ease and quiet.

questions.question: What do the worms do to those who lie down in the dust according to Job 21:26?
questions.correctAnswer: Cover them
questions.explanation: Job 21:26 says worms shall cover those who lie down alike in the dust.

questions.question: What do people say about the house of the prince and the dwelling places of the wicked in Job 21:28?
questions.correctAnswer: Where are they?
questions.explanation: Job 21:28 records people asking, 'Where is the house of the prince? and where are the dwelling places of the wicked?'

questions.question: True or False: Job 21:30 says the wicked are reserved for the day of destruction.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 21:30 states the wicked are reserved to the day of destruction and brought forth to the day of wrath.

questions.question: What remains in the tomb according to Job 21:32?
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked
questions.explanation: Job 21:32 says the wicked shall be brought to the grave and remain in the tomb.

medium.title: Job Chapter 21 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Job Chapter 21 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with doubt about God's justice because the wicked seem to prosper. Based on Job 21, what biblical truth would you share about God's judgment?
options: The wicked will ultimately face destruction and God's wrath despite temporary prosperity
The wicked always prosper without consequence
God ignores the deeds of the wicked
The wicked are blessed because God favors them
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked will ultimately face destruction and God's wrath despite temporary prosperity
questions.explanation: Job 21:17-20 and 30-32 teach that although the wicked may prosper for a time, God will bring destruction and judgment upon them. This shows God's ultimate justice.

questions.question: How does Job 21 teach us about facing trials and maintaining faith when the wicked seem to live comfortably?
options: We should understand that God's judgment is certain and not lose faith despite appearances
We should envy the wicked and seek their ways
We should abandon faith because it seems unfair
questions.correctAnswer: We should understand that God's judgment is certain and not lose faith despite appearances
questions.explanation: Verses 7-13 and 30-31 show the prosperity of the wicked, but verses 17-20 and 30-32 emphasize God's coming judgment. This teaches perseverance in faith.

questions.question: Job 21:5 says, 'Mark me, and be astonished, and lay your hand upon your mouth.' How does this teach humility and attentiveness in hearing God's message through others?
options: We should listen carefully and reflect in awe before responding
We should quickly interrupt and argue
We should mock those who speak
questions.correctAnswer: We should listen carefully and reflect in awe before responding
questions.explanation: Job 21:5 encourages attentive listening and reverent silence, which are marks of humility and respect in fellowship and spiritual discipline.

questions.question: According to Job 21:15, what question do the wicked ask that reflects a lack of reverence and faith in God, and what does this teach about prayer and obedience?
options: 'What is the Almighty, that we should serve him? and what profit should we have, if we pray unto him?' It teaches the importance of sincere reverence and prayer
'Why do we need to serve God?' which teaches that service is optional
'How can we avoid God?' which teaches avoidance of prayer
'What is the use of righteousness?' which teaches indifference to faith
questions.correctAnswer: 'What is the Almighty, that we should serve him? and what profit should we have, if we pray unto him?' It teaches the importance of sincere reverence and prayer
questions.explanation: Job 21:14-15 shows the wicked reject God's ways and prayer, teaching believers to value prayer and submission to God's will.

questions.question: A believer wonders about the brevity of life even for the prosperous. Based on Job 21:13 and 21:23-26, what biblical truth would you share about contentment and gratitude?
options: We all face death regardless of wealth, so be content and grateful for life’s blessings
Death is avoidable if one is wealthy
questions.correctAnswer: We all face death regardless of wealth, so be content and grateful for life’s blessings
questions.explanation: Job 21:13 and 23-26 contrast the prosperity and mortality of different people, teaching humility, contentment, and gratitude for God's gift of life.

questions.question: How does Job 21:22 challenge believers regarding God's knowledge and the humility needed in serving Him?
options: No one can teach God knowledge; He judges all, so we must be humble in serving Him
We can teach God if we are righteous
God is unaware of human actions
Only the wicked are judged by God
questions.correctAnswer: No one can teach God knowledge; He judges all, so we must be humble in serving Him
questions.explanation: Job 21:22 emphasizes God's supreme knowledge and authority, calling believers to humility and trust in His judgment.

questions.question: What does Job 21:3 teach about the importance of expressing one’s struggles and maintaining honesty in fellowship?
options: It encourages allowing oneself to speak honestly before being judged or mocked
It teaches to keep struggles hidden at all times
It suggests mocking others who speak
It advises silence in all suffering
questions.correctAnswer: It encourages allowing oneself to speak honestly before being judged or mocked
questions.explanation: Job 21:3 shows Job’s plea to speak openly, modeling honesty and transparency in spiritual community and personal devotion.

questions.question: True or False: Job 21 teaches that the wicked never face consequences for their actions.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 21:17-20 and 30-32 clearly state that the wicked will be brought to destruction and judgment by God, despite temporary prosperity.

questions.question: True or False: Job 21 encourages believers to take comfort in false answers when facing trials.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 21:34 warns that false answers provide no real comfort, teaching believers to seek truth and genuine consolation in God’s Word.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Job 21:11 says, 'They send forth their little ones like a _____, and their children dance.'
questions.correctAnswer: flock
questions.explanation: Job 21:11 uses the imagery of a 'flock' to describe the care and joy surrounding the children of the wicked, illustrating the temporary prosperity they experience.

questions.question: How does Job 21:4-6 help believers understand the value of expressing deep spiritual struggle honestly?
options: It acknowledges that even sincere complaints cause fear and trembling, emphasizing honesty in prayer and fellowship
It teaches that complaints should never be expressed
It suggests that spiritual struggle is a sign of unbelief
questions.correctAnswer: It acknowledges that even sincere complaints cause fear and trembling, emphasizing honesty in prayer and fellowship
questions.explanation: Verses 4-6 show Job’s honest expression of his troubled spirit, teaching believers to be transparent about their struggles before God and others.

questions.question: What does Job 21:28-30 teach about the certainty of divine justice for the wicked, and how should this encourage perseverance?
options: The wicked are reserved for the day of destruction and wrath, assuring believers that justice will prevail
Justice depends on human actions alone
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked are reserved for the day of destruction and wrath, assuring believers that justice will prevail
questions.explanation: These verses affirm God's ultimate justice, encouraging believers to persevere in faith despite present injustices.

questions.question: How does Job 21:12 describe the lifestyle of the wicked, and what does this imply about stewardship and contentment?
options: They rejoice with music and celebrations, showing that earthly wealth is temporary and should be stewarded wisely
They live in sorrow and fasting
They reject all joy and music
questions.correctAnswer: They rejoice with music and celebrations, showing that earthly wealth is temporary and should be stewarded wisely
questions.explanation: Verse 12 depicts the wicked’s indulgence, reminding believers to steward blessings with humility and prepare for eternal realities.

questions.question: In Job 21:29, what method does Job suggest we use to know the fate of the wicked, and how does this relate to evangelism and spiritual discipline?
options: Ask those who go by the way to learn from experience, encouraging sharing wisdom and spiritual vigilance
questions.correctAnswer: Ask those who go by the way to learn from experience, encouraging sharing wisdom and spiritual vigilance
questions.explanation: Job 21:29 models learning from others’ experiences, underscoring the importance of testimony and spiritual accountability in the faith community.

questions.question: How does Job 21:34 challenge believers in their approach to comforting others through spiritual counsel?
options: It warns against false comfort and urges truthful, sincere support grounded in God's truth
It encourages comforting with any words possible
questions.correctAnswer: It warns against false comfort and urges truthful, sincere support grounded in God's truth
questions.explanation: Verse 34 highlights the danger of false answers, teaching believers to provide honest and spiritually sound encouragement.

hard.title: Job Chapter 21 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Job Chapter 21.

questions.question: In Job 21, Job questions why the wicked live long and prosper. Which verse specifically expresses this inquiry?
questions.correctAnswer: Job 21:7
questions.explanation: Job 21:7 explicitly asks, "Wherefore do the wicked live, become old, yea, are mighty in power?" highlighting Job's questioning of the prosperity of the wicked.

questions.question: Which literary device is predominantly used in Job 21:18 with the phrase, "They are as stubble before the wind, and as chaff that the storm carrieth away"?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: The verse uses 'as' to compare the wicked to stubble and chaff, indicating a simile as the literary device.

questions.question: In the cultural context of ancient Near Eastern thought, what does Job 21:14's phrase "Depart from us; for we desire not the knowledge of thy ways" suggest about the attitude of the wicked toward God?
options: Rebellion and rejection of divine authority
questions.correctAnswer: Rebellion and rejection of divine authority
questions.explanation: Job 21:14 shows the wicked explicitly rejecting God's knowledge and presence, which reflects a rebellious attitude against divine authority common in ancient Near Eastern contexts.

questions.question: Which verse in Job 21 shows Job’s awareness of his friends’ hidden thoughts and accusations against him?
questions.explanation: Job 21:27 states, "Behold, I know your thoughts, and the devices which ye wrongfully imagine against me," explicitly showing Job's awareness of his friends' thoughts.

questions.question: In Job 21, which verse reflects a theological challenge to the notion that serving God brings material benefit, asking, 'What is the Almighty, that we should serve him?'
questions.explanation: Job 21:15 voices the skepticism of the wicked, questioning the value of serving God and praying to Him.

questions.question: How does Job 21:23-24 describe the condition of one who dies at ease, and which Old Testament imagery is used here?
options: Full strength, breasts full of milk, bones moistened with marrow
Weak and frail, bones brittle as dry wood
Covered in ashes and mourning garments
Falling like a leaf in autumn
questions.correctAnswer: Full strength, breasts full of milk, bones moistened with marrow
questions.explanation: These verses poetically describe prosperity and health at death using imagery of nourishment and strength, typical of ancient Near Eastern symbolism of well-being.

questions.question: True or False: Job 21:22 implies that humans can teach God knowledge, challenging divine omniscience.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 21:22 rhetorically asks, 'Shall any teach God knowledge?' implying that God is all-knowing and judges even the highest, so humans cannot teach Him.

questions.question: Which verse in Job 21 explains that the wicked will ultimately face destruction and wrath despite their apparent prosperity?
questions.explanation: Job 21:30 states that the wicked are reserved for the day of destruction and will face the day of wrath, indicating their ultimate judgment.

questions.question: The phrase 'the candle of the wicked' in Job 21:17 is an example of which Hebrew literary motif?
options: Symbolism of life as a lamp
questions.correctAnswer: Symbolism of life as a lamp
questions.explanation: In Hebrew literature, life is often symbolized as a lamp or candle; Job 21:17 uses this motif to describe the sudden end of the wicked’s life.

questions.question: In Job 21:10, what agricultural imagery is used to demonstrate the prosperity of the wicked?
options: Their bull gendereth and faileth not; their cow calveth and casteth not her calf
Their fields are parched and barren
Their sheep wander lost in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: Their bull gendereth and faileth not; their cow calveth and casteth not her calf
questions.explanation: This verse uses imagery of healthy, fertile livestock to illustrate the material prosperity of the wicked.

questions.question: What is the significance of Job 21:28-29’s rhetorical question about the house of the prince and dwelling places of the wicked in the context of ancient Israelite eschatology?
options: It challenges the friends to observe the fate of the wicked through history and prophecy
It praises the eternal security of the wicked
It describes the physical palaces built by kings
It references the building of the Temple in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: It challenges the friends to observe the fate of the wicked through history and prophecy
questions.explanation: The verses urge inquiry of travelers to confirm that the wicked’s houses do not endure, fitting with Israelite eschatological themes of eventual divine justice.

questions.question: How does Job 21:34 conclude Job’s argument against the false consolation of his friends?
options: By stating their answers contain falsehood
questions.correctAnswer: By stating their answers contain falsehood
questions.explanation: Job 21:34 says, 'How then comfort ye me in vain, seeing in your answers there remaineth falsehood?' showing Job’s rejection of their flawed arguments.

questions.question: Which theme in Job 21 is developed across Scripture, especially reflected in Psalms and Proverbs, regarding the prosperity and fate of the wicked?
questions.correctAnswer: Theodicy and divine justice
questions.explanation: Job 21’s discussion of wicked prosperity and eventual judgment echoes the theodicy theme found in Psalms and Proverbs, wrestling with divine justice.

questions.question: In Job 21:19-20, the concept that 'God layeth up his iniquity for his children' can be linked to which biblical principle?
questions.correctAnswer: Generational consequences of sin
questions.explanation: The verse reflects the ancient Near Eastern and biblical idea that the consequences of sin can affect descendants.

questions.question: Which term in Job 21:12 refers to a musical instrument, illustrating the celebration of the wicked?
questions.correctAnswer: Timbrel
questions.explanation: Job 21:12 mentions 'timbrel and harp,' showing the use of musical instruments in the rejoicing of the wicked.

theological.title: Job Chapter 21 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Job Chapter 21 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Job 21, what reason does Job give for asking why the wicked live long and prosper?
options: Because their seed is established before them and their houses are safe
Because they always repent and seek God
Because God does not see their deeds
questions.correctAnswer: Because their seed is established before them and their houses are safe
questions.explanation: Job 21:7-9 shows Job observing the prosperity of the wicked, noting their offspring are established and their houses safe. This theme echoes Psalm 73:3-12 and Ecclesiastes 8:14, where the prosperity of the wicked is also lamented, challenging simplistic retribution theology.

questions.question: According to Job 21, how do the wicked respond to God and His ways?
options: They say, 'Depart from us; we desire not the knowledge of thy ways.'
They seek God earnestly and repent
They fear God and keep His commandments
They pray for mercy and forgiveness
questions.correctAnswer: They say, 'Depart from us; we desire not the knowledge of thy ways.'
questions.explanation: Job 21:14 explicitly states the wicked reject God's knowledge, which aligns with Proverbs 1:24-26 and Romans 1:18-21 where sinners suppress the truth and reject divine revelation.

questions.question: What is Job's attitude toward the fate of the wicked as expressed in Job 21?
options: He acknowledges that God will ultimately bring destruction upon them
He believes the wicked will prosper forever without consequence
He denies any divine judgment against the wicked
He thinks the wicked escape punishment because they are powerful
questions.correctAnswer: He acknowledges that God will ultimately bring destruction upon them
questions.explanation: Job 21:17-20 explains that although the wicked prosper for a time, God 'distributeth sorrows in his anger' and will bring them to destruction, consistent with passages like Psalm 37:10-20 and Revelation 20:12-15.

questions.question: How does Job describe the physical condition of one who dies 'in his full strength' in Job 21?
options: His breasts are full of milk, and his bones are moistened with marrow
He is weak and frail with dry bones
He dies with great suffering and bitterness
questions.correctAnswer: His breasts are full of milk, and his bones are moistened with marrow
questions.explanation: Job 21:23-24 portrays one dying at ease with vitality intact. This imagery of physical fullness symbolizes health and blessing, paralleling Psalm 92:12-14 and Ecclesiastes 7:1 regarding the righteous flourishing before death.

questions.question: What rhetorical question does Job ask concerning teaching God knowledge in Job 21?
options: Shall any teach God knowledge? seeing he judgeth those that are high
Can man comprehend the wisdom of God?
Is it possible to hide from God's sight?
Can God make a mistake in judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: Shall any teach God knowledge? seeing he judgeth those that are high
questions.explanation: Job 21:22 challenges the arrogance of assuming humans can instruct God, emphasizing His sovereign judgment. This aligns with Isaiah 40:13-14 and Romans 11:33-34 that affirm God's incomprehensible wisdom.

questions.question: What does Job claim about the counsel of the wicked in Job 21?
options: Their good is not in their hand, and their counsel is far from him
Their plans are wise and profitable
Their advice should be followed carefully
They have secret knowledge from God
questions.correctAnswer: Their good is not in their hand, and their counsel is far from him
questions.explanation: Job 21:16 states that the good of the wicked is not lasting and their counsel is rejected by Job, reflecting Proverbs 14:12 and Jeremiah 10:23 about the futility of wicked plans apart from God's will.

questions.question: According to Job 21, what happens to both the righteous and the wicked in death?
options: They lie down alike in the dust, and worms cover them
The righteous ascend to heaven, the wicked to the grave
The wicked suffer eternal torment, the righteous rest
They are separated immediately after death
questions.correctAnswer: They lie down alike in the dust, and worms cover them
questions.explanation: Job 21:26 depicts the universal reality of death where all return to dust, resonating with Ecclesiastes 3:20 and Acts 3:23, emphasizing mortality as a shared human condition despite earthly differences.

questions.question: What accusation does Job make against his friends’ comfort in Job 21?
options: Their comfort is true and uplifting
Their words are inspired by the Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: Their answers contain falsehood
questions.explanation: Job 21:34 accuses his friends of offering vain and false comfort, which misrepresents God's justice, consistent with Job 13:4 and 16:2 where Job criticizes their unhelpful speeches.

questions.question: Which of the following best captures Job's concern about the wicked's offspring in Job 21?
options: Their seed is established in their sight and their children dance
Their descendants suffer for their sins
They have no offspring to carry on their name
Their children are cursed for their fathers’ wickedness
questions.correctAnswer: Their seed is established in their sight and their children dance
questions.explanation: Job 21:8 and 11 describe the prosperity and joy of the wicked’s children, highlighting the apparent contradiction to retribution theology, also seen in Psalm 37:25 and Jeremiah 12:1.

questions.question: How does Job describe the temporal nature of the wicked's prosperity in Job 21?
options: They spend their days in wealth but quickly go down to the grave
They grow richer every day and never face death
They are immune to death and judgment
questions.correctAnswer: They spend their days in wealth but quickly go down to the grave
questions.explanation: Job 21:13 portrays the fleeting nature of the wicked’s wealth and life, which aligns with James 4:13-14 and Psalm 49:10-12 emphasizing the brevity of life and the vanity of earthly riches.

questions.question: In Job 21, what is said about the wicked’s attitude toward serving the Almighty?
options: They question the profit of serving God and why they should pray to Him
They serve God faithfully and with reverence
They fear God’s wrath and repent
questions.correctAnswer: They question the profit of serving God and why they should pray to Him
questions.explanation: Job 21:15 reflects the rebellious mindset of the wicked who doubt the benefit of serving God, echoing sentiments found in Ecclesiastes 2:1-3 and Romans 3:10-12 about human rebellion.

questions.question: What metaphor does Job use in Job 21 to describe how God handles the wicked in judgment?
options: They are as stubble before the wind, and as chaff that the storm carries away
They are as mountains standing firm forever
They are like gold refined by fire
They are like trees planted by rivers of water
questions.correctAnswer: They are as stubble before the wind, and as chaff that the storm carries away
questions.explanation: Job 21:18 uses this metaphor to illustrate the frailty and impermanence of the wicked before God's judgment, consistent with Isaiah 17:13 and Matthew 3:12 which depict judgment as separating wheat from chaff.

questions.question: What does Job assert about the knowledge of God in relation to human teachers in Job 21?
options: No one can teach God knowledge because He judges the exalted
Humans can teach God if they are wise
God needs instruction from the angels
questions.correctAnswer: No one can teach God knowledge because He judges the exalted
questions.explanation: Job 21:22 emphasizes God's sovereignty and omniscience in judgment, rejecting human presumption to instruct Him, which aligns with Job 38:2-3 and Romans 11:33 highlighting divine wisdom beyond human reach.

questions.question: How does Job describe the fate of the wicked in relation to the day of destruction in Job 21?
options: The wicked are reserved until the day of destruction and brought forth to the day of wrath
The wicked escape the day of destruction
The wicked are immediately destroyed upon sinning
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked are reserved until the day of destruction and brought forth to the day of wrath
questions.explanation: Job 21:30 speaks of eschatological judgment reserved for the wicked, consonant with Daniel 12:1-2 and Revelation 20:12-15 describing final judgment and wrath.

questions.question: What does Job say about God's distribution of sorrows in Job 21?
options: God distributes sorrows in His anger to the wicked
God is indifferent to human sin
questions.correctAnswer: God distributes sorrows in His anger to the wicked
questions.explanation: Job 21:17 acknowledges God's righteous anger leading to judgment on the wicked, consistent with Nahum 1:2-3 and Romans 1:18 which speak of God's wrath against sin.
